Award.AbstractNarration:
Data in high dimensional spaces are now very common. This project will develop methods for analyzing these high dimensional data. Such data may contain hidden structures. For example, clusters (which are small regions with a large number of points) can be stretched out like a string forming a structure called a filament. Scientists in a variety of fields need to locate these objects. It is challenging since the data are often very noisy. This project will develop rigorously justified and computationally efficient methods for extracting such structures. The methods will be applied to a diverse set of problems in astrophysics, seismology, biology, and neuroscience. The project will advance knowledge in several fields including computational geometry, astronomy, machine learning, and statistics.

Finding hidden structure is useful for scientific discovery and dimension reduction. Much of the current theory on nonlinear dimension reduction assumes that the hidden structure is a smooth manifold and is very restrictive. The data might be concentrated near a low dimensional but very complicated set, such as a union of intersecting manifolds. Existing algorithms, such as the Subspace Constrained Mean Shift exhibit erratic behavior near intersections. This project will develop improved algorithms for these cases. At the same time, contemporary theory breaks down in these cases and this project will develop new theory to address the aforementioned problem. A complete method (which will be called singular clusters) will be developed for decomposing point clouds of varying dimensions into subsets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR AWARD NUMBER 1513412

The main goals of this award were: (i) Classifying hidden structures from large dimensional datasets, according to their local lower dimension. (ii) Identifying local maxima in multivariate estimated probability distributions for studying important (or unknown) features in data sets. (iii) Selecting tuning parameters.
Our aim was to build a statistical theory for classifying low dimensional structures hidden in larger dimension point clouds. 
For example, data can be observed in many dimension, larger than two or three, corresponding to the number of variables that influence an outcome of interest. As a more concrete illustration, consider the likelihood of having a stroke. This event  might be influenced by several factors, like age, gender, blood pressure, diabetes, sleep apnea, and other variables, that can be measured in a sample of a population. Visualizing these type of factors in more than three dimensions is not viable. But, often, simpler relationships among variables might be hidden in a smaller dimensional space, meaning that a smaller number of variables might be considered for studying the issue at hand.
Expanding on our previous work (e.g. on two our previous papers:"Minimax Manifold Estimation" which appeared in The Journal of Machine Learning Research, 2012, and "Nonparametric Ridge Estimator", which appeared in "The Annals of Statistics", 2014) we developed theoretical methods, and presented applications to identify unexpected or unknown structures hidden in a large dimensional space. We identified several steps for the procedure, since these lower dimensional structures are sets with zero Lebesgue measure with respect to the D-dimensional ambient space. We first obtained an estimate of the underlying D-dimensional probability density function from which data were generated. Second, we searched for ridges in the estimated density. These two steps were then followed by a filtering step based on the eigenvalues of the Hessian of the estimated density.We also derived nonparametric confidence intervals for the eigenvalues of the Hessian at modes of a density estimate.
Our results were presented at a number of international meetingsand appeared on peer reviewed journals. More specifically:

Chen Y. C., Ho, S., Freeman, P. E., Genovese, C. R, and Wasserman, L. (2015). Cosmic Web Reconstruction through Density Ridges: Method and Algorithm.Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society vol 454.1.

Chen Y. C., Ho, S., Ananth Tenneti, A., Mandelbaum, R., Croft, R., DiMatteo, T., Freeman, P. E., Genovese, C. R, and Wasserman, L. (2015). Investigating Galaxy­Filament Alignments in Hydrodynamic Simulations using Density Ridges. Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society. Vol. 454.5.

Chen, Y. C., Wang, D., Rinaldo, A., and Wasserman, L. (2015). Statistical analysis of persistence intensity functions. arXiv:1510.02502.

Chen Y. C., Genovese, C. R., and Wasserman, L (2015).Asymptotic theory for density ridges. Annals of Statistics. Vol 43.

Genovese, C. R., Perone-Pacifico, M., Verdinelli, I. and Wasserman, L. (2016). Nonparametric Inference For Density Modes. J. R. Statist. Soc. B. Vol. 99.

Genovese, C. R., Perone-Pacifico, M., Verdinelli, I. and Wasserman, L. (2017). Finding Singular Features. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics vol. 26. 

Chen, Y. C., Genovese, C. R., and Wasserman, L. (2017). Statistical Inference using the Morse­Smale Complex. Electronic Journal of Statistics. Vol 11.
Chen, Y. C., Genovese, C. R., and Wasserman, L. (2017). Density level sets: Asymptotics, inference, and visualization. Journal of the American Statistical Association. Vol. 112

Wasserman, L. (2018). Topological data analysis. Annual Review of Statistics and Its Application. Vol 5.
Verdinelli, I., and Wasserman, L. (2018). Analysis of a Mode Clustering Diagram. To appear in Electronic Journal of Statistics.
